## Anna Karenina Ballet - Maya Plisetskaya and Rodion Shchedrin

Plisetskaya's husband, composer Rodion Shchedrin, wrote the score to a number of her ballets, including Anna Karenina, The Sea Gull, Carmen, and Lady with a Small Dog.(no content)The title sheet of the score has a dedication "To Maya Plisetskaya, always". The great ballet dancer and the composer's spouse to whom Shchedrin's other ballets were dedicated as well (Carmen Suite, The Seagull, The Lady with the Lapdog) was an initiator of creation of this work.

### Ballet Production Details

The premiere took place at the Bolshoi Theatre in 1971.(no content)Anna Karenina was also her first attempt at choreography.(no content)Choreography is by Maya Plisetskaya & Natalia Rizhenko.(no content)Valeri Levental designed the stage setting and Pierre Cardin created the costumes. Yuri Temirkanov, the chief conductor of the Bolshoi Theatre was at the stand.

### Success and Performance History

The ballet Anna Karenina was one of the most successful productions of the Bolshoi Theatre in the 1970s and 1980s. It was shown more than a hundred times during 13 years.

### Musical Composition and Style

Shchedrin turned to Leo Tolstoy's novel after he composed the score for the motion picture Anna Karenina (1967) where Maya Plisetskaya acted as a dramatic actress.(no content)As a basis, Shchedrin took the concept of Tchaikovsky's "lyrical scenes" – his opera Eugene Onegin, - uncovering the heroine's and other characters' spiritual world through solo and ensemble ballet scenes. Shchedrin deliberately used musical quotations from the great Russian composer's works created in the first half of the 1870s, the years when Tolstoy worked on his novel.

### Film and Media Adaptations

The film is a Bolshoi Ballet version of Leo Tolstoy's 1877 novel Anna Karenina with choreography by Maya Plisetskaya who also took on the title role. A 1975 film version was made, and Maya Plisetskaya, Mikhail Petukhov, and Victor Barykin perform in this 1980 Bolshoi Ballet production of the Shchedrin ballet conducted by Yuri Simonov.

### International Recognition

In 1962, the Bolshoi was invited to perform at the White House by president John F. Kennedy, and Plisetskaya recalled that first lady Jacqueline Kennedy greeted her by saying "You're just like Anna Karenina."

The Anna Karenina ballet represents one of the most significant collaborations between Maya Plisetskaya and Rodion Shchedrin, showcasing both her dancing and choreographic talents while featuring his innovative musical adaptation of Tolstoy's masterpiece.
